posts.sub: How to sleep while on aripiprazole
posts.com: So i started taking this shit (15mg) yesterday and i didnt sleep, from yesterday to today i have at most like 2 hours of collective sleep, so i took another pill today and when i started to feel like im not going to sleep again today, i was looking on the web and people said they get insomnia even with smaller doses, so... what's a good trick to sleep even with this shitty side effect? (im going to stop taking it but i want to sleep tonight)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28259114
Did you start this treatment as a replacement for another or is the first molecule they had you try?
In the first case, it is possible that the insomnia is caused not by the taking of aripiprazole, but by the withdrawal of the previous treatment you were taking.
In the second case, have you not been prescribed an if-needed complementary benzo? If so, take it, it might help.
Last question, when are you taking it? It can be helpful to take in the morning in order to avoid this type of side effect.
Do advise your doctor if you do decide to stop the treatment, it can take a while to find the right one, but taking none at all isn't the answer. Good luck to you.

Sounds like a plan. I know it's shit to have to take neuroleptics, it's a pain in the ass, they have side effects, they remind you of something out of your control you'd rather forget, and you sometimes doubt their effectiveness. I'd just like to point out, that, in my humble experience, the people who, from early on in their treatment, manage to stick with the pills/injections tend to have less episodes in the future (they do have to find the right molecule first, though, obviously). Going on and off medication tends to lower their potency, and the more episodes, the more resistant to medication the problem gets. Just a thought. I hope you get your sleep back. Some of these side effects are also known to not last very long, they just go away, sometimes, once your body adjusts. Again, wishing you good luck.

To go on a tangent here, I don't believe that depression and anxiety are mental illnesses in the same way as, say, PTSD, but rather symptoms. I have ADHD and possibly ASD, but never got diagnosed as a child, and also had very neglectful parents. Add high expectations Vs poor performance and bullying on top. I was depressed for almost 2 decades with 2 attempts of suicide, self-harm and drug abuse, plus social anxiety. I've gotten over the social anxiety, stopped taking drugs (barring caffeine and nicotine) and largely managed to improve my depressive symptoms. Learning where this all came from helped immensely with working through it and reframing everything that happened to me, and also gave me a lot of resilience and led me to unlearn unhealthy coping mechanisms and replace them with healthy ones. I'd say I'm still not what you'd call completely mentally sound but it's a slow upward spiral with the occasional bump in the road.

>>28259947
>what are some exercises that can be used to overcome fear of rejection
The best exercise is to do small things that would cause rejection, but not hurt badly. For example, join an online community and share your hobbies with others. When you are rejected, it will not hurt badly, but it will be an opportunity for you to learn to overcome that fear. After many rejections, you will learn to accept it and improve yourself. However, if you never attempt to do this exercise, then you will always be afraid.

>is there some kind of training exercise to combat impostor syndrome
That is a good question. Yes, there is a training exercise you can try. Every day, you must talk to yourself in the mirror, and tell yourself your accomplishments. You must do this every day to build up your self-esteem and self-confidence, until you can look in the mirror and accept yourself. Once you can accept yourself in front of the mirror, you will learn to overcome your fear of being an "imposter".

>what do you, personally, think about tarot reading?
I think it is a superstitious practice that can sometimes be psychologically dangerous. I do not believe in mystical fortune. I believe our destiny is in our hands. That said, the human brain is easily stimulated through placebo, and so I do believe that for those who believe in tarot, it can become something real.

>>28259988
You're very welcome, Comfort Lion.

>>28259992
>How does one deal with being neglected by their parents?
Neglect can be hard for a child to deal with, no matter what age. It makes them feel as though they are not worth their parents' attention. They may believe that they are the cause of the neglect, when in reality it is often the parents who are to blame for their inattention. You should try to find a way to accept that this was not your fault, and that the actions of your parents do not represent your worth.

You can do this in a few different ways: One way is to remind yourself that the actions of your parents say nothing about who you are as a person. You are good and loving, and you deserve love and happiness.

Another way is to look at yourself as you would a friend. If you had a friend who was experiencing this situation, how would you support them? It is often easier to be kind to others than we are to ourselves.

>How do i stop procrastinating?
One of the main reasons people procrastinate is because they are afraid of failure. You want to do good work, but you worry something will go wrong if you start. So, you put it off in order to avoid that possibility. If you try and focus on getting started, rather than looking at the task as a whole, it should be easier to start and finish.

>Also, how do you know if a girl is flirting/interested in you vs just being nice and keeping the social peace?
If she shows you a lot of attention, if she often asks you questions, and if she makes herself seem available, you can be sure that she is interested. But you shouldn't be afraid to just ask. If a girl is really interested, she will not only let you know, but also show you. That way you don't have to guess anymore.

I have dealt with people who have gone through this, as well as people who did not take such action. You do not feel as though you have found your place in this world, and you still have many emotional and physical connections to your past. I can tell you that it does not make a difference to escape your past. Even if you move a thousand miles away, you cannot escape yourself.

What you need is a new start, not a new place. By this I mean that you need to take the time and reevaluate your life, discover what makes you happy, discover what truly matters to you. What are your values? What are your needs? What makes you *you* and what do you want to become? Your life can only begin if you allow it to.

>>28259020
Keep having convos that (even if they) go nowhere , talk to people who want to talk , u have to make conversation out of nothing , but u have to be careful not to overdo it and be annoying about it .
It’s tricky because it’s a fine line and there’s no formula , but it’s easy because the most important thing u can do is listen , as in listen (in the moment) to whether ur coworkers want to talk , some people are chatty , some people aren’t ,
If ur paying attention u can tell when someone wants to make conversation , and u can tell when someone is tired of talking .
It (ur conversation throughout the workday) will ebb and flow like a good album , u can’t be chatty all day , but it’s nice to get into it for a bit . Ride the crescendo of convo but don’t force it and give it (the conversation) room to breathe .
Subject matter isn’t that important , talk about the things that are on ur mind and listen to (entice/draw out) what’s on ur coworkers minds

>Asked a waitress out
Here is a protip that I have had to tell some of my IRL friends.
DO. NOT. ASK. SERVERS. OUT.
These people are working their job. Their job is to be pleasant and sometimes slightly flirty with customers to provide a good experience out. They do this to get more tips.

Would you assume that a hooker you paid for liked you because you had sex with them? No. You wouldn't assume that because that is their job.

The same goes for servers. They are doing their job by and large. So, 99% of the time, if a server is friendly with you, it is just them doing their job.

Do not mistake hospitality with affection, and you can avoid a lot of embarrassment going forward.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Naltrexone for addiction treatment

Addicts have impulses that drive them back to certain behaviors. Understanding that the behavior is harmful, along with a resolve to quit frequently is not enough, because the powerful urge or cravings exist far apart from rational thinking. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders: a malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28258069
What keeps me sober is knowing that diving back in would make me lose myself again. That may seem like a temporarily alluring prospect, who doesn't want to escape from themselves? That's why most of us use, isn't it? It's understanding that temporary escape quickly becomes full time escape and with it comes depression, anxiety, weight gain, irritability, inability to cope, anger, loss of interest in life, damage to relationships, loss of interest in hobbies, loss of athleticism, regular feeling like shit, etc.

Now, it's not as easy as just quitting. You have mental struggles that cause you to drink and you need to find a better way to cope with them. Exercise works for me, it gives me something to pour myself into, build discipline, and better my overall health. You don't have to exercise, but you need to find a healthy outlet that can substitute as a coping mechanism for drinking. I am never dissatisfied with myself for working out (quite the opposite); I would be dissatisfied with myself for getting fucked up and feeling like shit the next day. Sometimes, you have to be your own parent and do not what's easy and what you want to do, but tell your brain who's boss and do what's best for your overall well being despite your urges.

Another anon said it, it won't happen unless you find a reason that resonates with you to be better. You have to find that and no one else can. Support groups sound cliche, but they can give you purpose and a leg up. I don't vibe with AA, you might though so don't rule it out. SMART worked for me, which is a group about self empowerment and cognitive behavioral therapy; teaches you to understand your decisions, think about them logically, and change your behavior.

Good luck, anon. If you truly want it, you can do it. Life is short and only you can change your circumstance.

I mean, even if you don't directly call it a date, going mini golfing as a pair is a pretty clear date. So if you're worried about spooking her by being too formal, I think you're safe just asking her to go with you and feeling it out on the night. Having the activity to occupy you (and drinks) should make for a fun, smooth evening.
The only pitfall might be if she's not as aware of your interest as you think, AND she's just not interested in mini golf as a concept, in which case you might find yourself with a phantom rejection, where she might have gone out with you if she'd known it was a date but you're left too gunshy to try again. So if she does say no, and it seems genuinely focused on the concept of mini golf rather than the concept of spending time with you, I'd stay optimistic and just have a more clear backup in your pocket, like a simple "well it doesn't have to be mini golf, I just like hanging out with you."

>> how men today are soft and we're not bred for hard times

He's mostly correct. Millennials and younger are a weak, waste of oxygen generation that can't handle basic life let alone anything hard. Just generations of snowflakes. People saying ludicrous things now like words cause physical harm, because people are so weak they can't even handle criticism anymore.

>> What steps can I to better myself as a man?

Well you answered some of them yourself in your post.

>> I've had social anxiety my whole life

Get over it. Harden up and put your fear aside.

>> I've never had a job

Change that

>> or went to college

Change that too. Try some short courses first, like introduction to philosophy to get your brain moving.

>> I do workout, though

Exercise has nothing to do with being a man. Exercise is also a separate add on to living an active lifestyle. That's what you should be focusing on in terms of health & fitness.

In terms of other traits. You need to develop emotional fortitude, remember the old saying sticks and stones can break my bones, but names will never hurt me. People's words or ideas should never be so threatening to you or hurtful that they cause uncontrollable emotions.

Get yourself out of your echo chamber and into a diverse mix of opinions, thoughts and ideas. Hear what other people are saying, really listen and evaluate them critically. Some of their ideas will be good even though you never thought about them, or potentially even previously disagreed. Some will be bad, but then so are some of your own ideas.

Learn how to be self critical. What is it that you believe, why do you honestly believe that, what evidence is there, how does it genuinely stack up?

Be prepared to be challenged and be ok with that. It's not an attack on you, so stop tying your ideas to your ego. Be prepared to lose sometimes, that's ok too. Everyone has bad ideas at least some of the time.

posts.name: Mr Man
posts.com:
[2/X]

Learn integrity, take responsibility and stop seeking respect from outside of you...learn to respect yourself. Get to a place where you love yourself and think of yourself as a worthy person comfortable in their own skin. Stop acting like a girl with all the self doubt, anxiety and neurosis.

Sometimes having integrity means admitting you were in the wrong and taking your licks whatever they might be. Even if those licks mean you get beat down. Sometimes you deserve that and you have to be ready to accept it.

Let go of that crazy ego, understand we all start at the bottom and EARN the respect and trust of others over time. That you aren't owed anything, ever. That your safety and well-being are always primarily your responsibility. Stop trying to debate things you don't understand. Ask for help when you need it and be gracious in the help that you receive.

Act with honour, and honour yours and your loved ones. That means treating others how you'd like to be treated. It means going out of your way sometimes to help others. It means knowing when to lead, and when to follow. But mostly it means approaching the world around you with kindness.


Get into camping, then survivalism. Learn how to rough it and to survive in much less than ideal conditions. Get right with nature and ok with not being connected to the internet. Learn what you can eat, and what you can't. Learn how to build things with your own hands, things that can help you survive. Learn how machines work and how to fix things. Become self sufficient. Understand that luxuries and rights are nice to have, but that any of them can be taken away at any moment and you need to be capable of adjusting quickly.

posts.name: Mr Man
posts.com:
[3/X]

Find yourself a male role model.

Learn courage and how to work well with others. Therapy might be good for you. Don't be afraid to ever ask for help. Learn what strength actually means, both emotionally and physically. Develop some ambition.

There's so much more but my phone is going flat so I don't have time to write it.

>>28259075
daily walk, an hour each day. Even monks and prisonners get that much and you owe it to yourself.
I'm a former NEET so I know when you're so entrenched in that NEET life the only stimulus are on a screen and there's 0 physical exercise. Going out for a walk you're suddenly seeing and experiencing new things, and smelling them too.
I remember the sound of crickets in the summer and then mostly just the silent woosh of wind in the winter was really nice but above all it was my sense of smell that really woke up the most when i started leaving my room.

Anyways, get some basic 'apartment gym' equipment like chest expanders, those small one hand grip trainers, the thing that's a metal spring/bar you have to bend, a kettlebell is very versatile and takes up less space than barbells or even dumbbells.

Reading is nice too, just regular old books ideally the real ink on paper deal. It's better than a audiobook or e-book or movie adaptation of a book in that your attention is completely focused and your imagination is activated.

>>28258751

To address the point you made in OP about having her stuck in your head, what I figured out for myself (and later realized is essentially cognitive-behavioral therapy) is as you're going about your day pay attention to how your thoughts flow. Start noticing when your thoughts take you somewhere you don't want to be. When you get into a line of thinking you don't want to be in, figure out something you can just quickly snap your brain to doing. When I was paying off my student loans, I'd say "money, money, money" in my head and it'd click me into doing mental math on my debt. It can be anything distracting in a preferably positive sense. Planning a goal you're working towards, thinking about strats for a game you enjoy, anything and it'll likely change for you over time so just go with the flow of whatever you find keeps you from ruminating in the dark crevasses of your mind that you don't want to spend time in. Do this whole process with a sense of calm and mental tranquility, I mentally visualize softly pushing thoughts out of my head that I know are bad for me but find whatever works for you.

A big eureka for me in this process was running across a quote from some swami that ran to the effect of: "If you're trying to get through a crowd, you do not walk up to each man and fight him. You flow between them. So too when you thoughts disturb you, do not wrestle with them individually but slip away from them sleek as a fish."

Don't fight your thoughts just learn for them to be there and that you choose whether you interact with them. Brush them aside if they are unwanted and continue whatever path you do wish to follow.

Stop masturbating all the time, like do it max once a week. One nut, not one session.

You know when you’re in your head daydreaming about whatever scenario? The fake ones where you say some one liner or whatever, or you have a conversation that goes this certain way, you know the ones I mean. Stop doing that. No more daydreaming about fantasy scenarios at all, no more plugging yourself into anything and acting it out. It makes you think conversations have to go a certain way, which brings me to my next point.

Conversations don’t have to be perfect, most of them are pretty benign and you might get a one liner or two, unless it’s your best friends or someone you really click with. Conversations don’t have to be perfect and if you totally fuck it up, it doesn’t matter. If you’re in a city you probably won’t see most people you see ever again anyway. As long as you’re a good person to people, they’ll generally be patient with your socially inept ass, and if they aren’t then fuck them you didn’t want to talk to them anyway.

You don’t have to drag conversations out indefinitely, when it goes quiet just enjoy the silence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First of all you need exposure. You need to talk to people to become comfortable around them and you need constant practice otherwise you'll get rusty, remember all those people who said they become anxious and felt like they lost social skills during the pandemic lockdown shit? I've found that I can go without socialising for maybe 3 days before I become more anxious. There really is no skip around for this, you need to talk to a variety of real people (not online).

In addition to all that you kind of need to understand where other people are coming from. From my experience with SA and from knowing many other people with it, we tend to think of other people as fundamentally different to us, like they are just inherently sinister or judgemental towards you. This is not the case, remember people are just like you. They have wants and needs and if they are going to judge you and treat you badly you have to ask yourself under what conditions youd do the same to another human being. Probably when you are in a really bad mood or feeling insecure or just plain ignorant of others sensitivity to things.
